data.description: Huge mountains, rugged foothills, deep canyons, vast caverns, and the worldâ€™s largest trees exemplify the diversity of landscapes, life, and beauty here. Explore these pages to plan your visit or to learn about the plants and animals here and the threats they face. Ancient giant sequoias may seem invincible, but they, too are vulnerable.

entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling in a single vehicle for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This entry fee is for a single person traveling on foot or by bicycle. It is valid for 1-7 days in Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling on a motorcycle, scooter, or similar motorized vehicle for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups traveling in vehicles that have a capacity of up to 15 passengers pay a $35 vehicle entrance fee or use a park pass. Groups traveling in a bus or vehicle with a capacity of 16 persons or more are charged $20 per person, up to the maximums listed for commercial groups with comparable passenger capacity ($100 or $200). People 15 years old or younger, anyone with a pass that may be used for park entry, and drivers hired for transportation only are exempt from the per person fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 7-15 people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 16-25 people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 26 or more people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: The charge for vehicles with a seating capacity of 1-6 passengers is $25, plus $20 per passenger, with a maximum total fee of $75. This entrance fee is for commercial tours of one or more people traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: The per person fee for vehicles with a seating capacity of 1-6 passengers is $20, plus $25 per vehicle, with a maximum total fee of $75. This entrance fee is for commercial tours of one or more people traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake Ranger District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument for one year from the month of purchase. The pass admits all passengers in a private vehicle and is non-transferable.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Two highways enter the parks. Hwy 180 from Fresno leads east to Kings Canyon National Park, then continues 30 miles east to Cedar Grove. Hwy 198 from Visalia leads east to Sequoia National Park via Three Rivers. Inside the parks, Highway 198 becomes the Generals Highway, which connects 198 to 180. Vehicles over 22-feet long should enter the parks via Highway 180. In winter, the Generals Highway between the parks often closes. Chains may be required on park roads. No roads cross the parks east to west.

operatingHours.description: The parks are open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Some park roads and roads that access more remote parts of the parks close in the winter due to snow accumulation. Rarely, extreme weather conditions may cause roads into the parks to be closed.
operatingHours.name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks

images.title: Kings Canyon
images.altText: A deep canyon with a forested floor and steep granite cliffs
images.caption: The Glaciers carved the Kings Canyon's steep granite cliffs, leaving a wide U-shaped valley.

images.title: The Tablelands
images.altText: A steep granite slope leads from forest to a bare alpine landscape
images.caption: Just above Lodgepole Valley, the trail to the Watchtower offers views above the treeline.

images.title: Moro Rock
images.altText: A guardrail encircles people along a narrow walkway with wide views
images.caption: A historic stairway leads to the top of Moro Rock, offering views from foothills to peaks

images.title: Giant Sequoia in Winter
images.altText: A giant sequoia's reddish bark contrasts with the snow around it
images.caption: For those who don't mind icy roads, winter offers stunning views of sequoias in snow.

images.title: Giant Forest Museum
images.altText: A rustic building is surrounded by giant sequoias
images.caption: Giant Forest Museum offers exhibits, park information, and a bookstore.

data.weatherInfo: Because of the extreme elevation range in the parks, weather conditions vary widely between areas. In summer, the sequoia groves have comfortable temperatures and the foothills are hot and dry. Snow lingers on high-mountain passes well into summer. In fall, conditions can range from summer-like to winter-like. Winter brings snow to sequoia groves and rain to the foothills. Be prepared for tire chain requirements. Spring is a great time to hike in the foothills and snow begins to melt at higher elevations.
data.name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon
